DOCNAME: CASE OF THE NATIONAL & PROVINCIAL BUILDING SOCIETY, THE LEEDS PERMANENT BUILDING SOCIETY AND THE YORKSHIRE BUILDING SOCIETY v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: No violation of P1-1;No violation of Art. 14+P1-1;No violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 14+6-1
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were at all relevant times building societies within the meaning of LAW DATE . Building societies operate under the status of “ mutual societies ” under LANGUAGE law as opposed to the status enjoyed by companies under company law . A building society ’s members are made up of its investors who deposit savings with it and receive a rate of interest or a dividend in return , and its borrowers who are charged interest on their loans . By and large , loans are taken out by borrowers to buy private residential property .

CARDINAL . Investors with a building society are liable to pay income tax in respect of the interest earned on their deposits . The income tax owed to ORG for the purposes of DATE to CARDINAL DATE of DATE was in practice calculated or measured with reference to a period of equal length preceding DATE . The so - called “ measurement principle ” required that the period measured be always equal in length to the period taxed . The taxpayer was not in fact taxed on the income of DATE but assessed to tax on the income received in DATE , the amount of DATE income being artificially computed by reference to the income of DATE . Accordingly , in normal circumstances , individual investors with building societies would be obliged to declare in their tax returns for DATE in question the amount of interest or dividends earned on their deposits in a preceding reference period of equal length to DATE , and the Inland Revenue would have to make individual assessments to tax on the strength of the information supplied by the investor .

NORP However , in view of the very large number of building society investors , many of whom had only modest savings and were thus only liable to small amounts of income tax , or to no tax at all , it had for many years up to and including DATE CARDINAL/CARDINAL been the practice for ORG to make voluntary arrangements with building societies for the payment by each society of a single annual composite amount . The effect of this payment by a building society was to discharge its investors’ liability to income tax at the basic rate on the interest which they earned . These arrangements , which were for DATE operated on a non - statutory basis , were at the relevant time given statutory recognition under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG DATE “ the DATE LAW .

CARDINAL . The composite - rate payment under the voluntary arrangements was calculated for DATE by reference to the global amount of interest paid by the society to its investors . However , in order to reflect the fact that some of the investors would not have been liable to tax at all given the modest amounts of their savings ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) a reduced rate of tax was applied . For this reason the annual ORG payments made under this scheme were known as “ reduced - rate tax ” or “ composite - rate tax ” , or “ ORG ” .

CARDINAL . The amount paid to investors by way of interest on their investments took account of the fact that their liability to income tax was discharged by the building society via the payment of ORG to ORG . Investors thus received their interest net of tax .

CARDINAL . In accordance with the “ revenue - neutrality ” principle , set out in section CARDINAL of LAW DATE , the ORG payment reflected only the amount which would have been paid by the investors themselves had they been obliged to declare and pay tax on the interest they earned through their deposits .

CARDINAL . Lord PERSON , delivering the judgment of the majority , concluded :

“ ... I confess that I find the conclusion irresistible that ORG intended by these words [ section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ] to enable the Revenue to take account of and to charge to tax sums which , rightly or wrongly , it regarded as otherwise representing windfalls in the hands of building societies . CARDINAL has only to look at the circumstances . LAW had been made and had been objected to . They were made the subject of a direct challenge in legal proceedings , the evidence in support of which clearly adumbrated the arguments advanced before the judge and ORG . The notion that ORG should go to the trouble of enacting an expressly retrospective amendment in order to provide , unnecessarily , for the use of these sums as a measurement of tax liability – a matter never remotely in issue – is simply fanciful ...

... I am bound to say that I think it unfortunate that the Revenue , through ORG , should have chosen by secondary rather than primary legislation to take what was , on ordinary principles , the very unusual course of seeking to tax more than DATE income in DATE of assessment , but section CARDINAL of LAW DATE is , on any analysis , a very unusual provision and I have , in the end , found myself irresistibly driven to the conclusion that this was what ORG intended should occur . But even making that assumption it amounts to no more than saying that the legislature should not have intended to do that which it plainly set out to do . I would , for my part , therefore , reject the ORG ’s principal argument . ”
